docs.lead_paragraph: A Minnesota fertility clinic has offered a guarantee that men who have vasectomies reversed there will able to produce a pregnancy or it will pay for another fertility procedure. Reproductive Medicine and Infertility Associates of St. Paul said it was the first center to make such an offer, which includes a $6,000 credit to pay for another fertility technique if its vasectomy reversal fails to yield a pregnancy within a year. A vasectomy is a common surgical sterilization procedure that blocks the flow of sperm through a vessel known as the vas deferens.

headline.main: Help for Vasectomy Reversals That Fail

docs.abstract: Reproductive Medicine and Infertility Associates in St Paul, Minn, offers guarantee that men who have vasectomies reversed there will be able to produce a pregnancy or it will pay for another fertility procedure (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Signaling his willingness to maintain a highly visible role in the fight against abortion, Bishop James T. McHugh, the new spiritual leader of Long Island's 1.3 million Roman Catholics, led a peaceful rally here this morning outside a Planned Parenthood clinic. The protest began with a morning Mass at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church here, where Bishop McHugh called on 700 members of the congregation to pray for an end to abortions and ''for the removal of this dark stain that has cast a blight across our great country.''

headline.main: New Roman Catholic Leader Protests Abortion at Rally Outside Clinic

docs.abstract: Bishop James T McHugh, Long Island's new Roman Catholic bishop, signals his willingness to maintain highly visible role in anti-abortion fight by leading peaceful rally outside Planned Parenthood clinic, Smithtown, NY; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As I read David Samuels's article (March 21), I found myself overwhelmed by the negativity of the anti-abortion movement. Just once, I'd like to hear about someone doing something positive to remedy the root problem: unwanted pregnancy. Where are these protesters when schools try to institute comprehensive programs of sex education that teach both abstinence and contraception? Nobody visits an abortion provider on a whim. Please don't print my name. The last thing I need is a bunch of zealots with too much time on their hands bothering my neighbors.
docs.abstract: Anonymous letter on David Samuels's Mar 21 article deplores negativity of anti-abortion movement; photo

docs.lead_paragraph: SOMETIME in the early morning hours of Sept. 17, 1995, a 7-month-old boy, Alexander Williamson-Noble, died of SIDS. He was survived by his parents, his twin brother, Robert, an older sister, Florentina, and another brother, Andrew. What makes Alexander more than a statistic is that in his death, he became the driving force for the Considering Alexander Foundation, started by his parents, Esmeralda and Hugh Williamson-Noble. ''No one asked if we were willing to give up our child,'' Mrs. Williamson-Noble said recently. ''Alexander was just stolen from us. Since crib death wrenched our son from us, we've vowed to go after this killer, day after day, until it is stamped off the face of the earth.''

headline.main: Baby's Death Leads To a Foundation To Aid Other Infants

docs.abstract: Article on Considering Alexander Foundation in Irvington, NY, founded by Esmeralda and Hugh Williamson-Noble, whose 7-month-old son died of Sudden Infant Death Syndrome in September 1995 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Nine years ago, after reports that pregnant inmates were being kept in shackles during labor and delivery, a Federal court ordered the New York City Department of Correction to stop the practice. It also prohibited the routine shackling of inmates after they had given birth, requiring the department to consult a physician before using restraints. But now, prisoners and their advocates say, female inmates who are taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens are again being shackled routinely after giving birth, and, in some cases, during delivery, in violation of the court decree.

headline.main: Inmates Again Shackled During Birth, Critics Say

docs.abstract: Prisoners and their advocates charge that female inmates taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center, Queens, are again being shackled routinely after giving birth, and sometimes during delivery, in violation of Federal court order; Correction Department defends use of restraints in recovery rooms; denies shackling during labor or delivery (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With Congress reconvening next week, President Clinton flew here today to try to whip up public enthusiasm for the Democratic proposal to establish a ''patient's bill of rights.'' Mr. Clinton told a group of about 400 union workers and health care providers that he had advocated the patients program until he was ''blue in the face,'' but he wanted the public to express its support by signing a petition on the Internet to counter the opposition of large health maintenance organizations and insurance companies.

headline.main: Clinton Urges Petition Drive to Pass Health Plan

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton addresses group of health care providers in Philadelphia, Pa, as he tries to whip up public enthusiasm for Democratic proposal to establish 'patient's bill of rights'; calls on public to sign petition on Internet to counter opposition of large health maintenance organizations and insurance companies; says Republican-controlled Congress will not feel any pressure to act on matter unless there is clear demand from public; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In New York, the Fitzpatrick Manhattan Hotel was bracing for it. With night approaching, the manager was reporting a rush of last-minute orders for bouquets and requests for dinner reservations at the most romantic spots in town. In Boston, WJMN radio was promoting it. The station had sequestered four lucky couples in a hotel, all competing for the same prize -- and a measure of celebrity.

headline.main: Another Countdown to the Millennium Begins

docs.abstract: Notion of conceiving baby that will be born on Jan 1, 2000, provokes marketing frenzy, turning most intimate of decisions and actions into public spectacle of sorts; 1,000 people have purchased Millennium Conception Kits, for $49.99, that include ovulation detection tests, pregnancy tests, candles and massage oils; radio stations and hotels around nation are offering prizes to first local baby born on Jan 1 (M)
